B00004RF9I|5.0|Mr. Chayevsky has made, easily, one of the greatest contributions to the art of cinema; one that transcends mere entertainment and holds court within the realm of the social, psychological, and political.<br />My fellow reviewers have been eloquent in pointing out the details, merits, and slight flaws within this movie.<br /><br />With the exception of the brutal murder on the air, every single outrageous idea that the film is now, 30+ years later, part and parcel of standard TV programming. The most banal mediocrities, the most mindless sensationalism, the most blatant lies, are all so common on modern TV that it not only goes unnoticed, but is accepted as being good programming. Even people who know they're looking at mind destroying garbage continue to watch it!! All fo this was warned about in the movie; all of it has come to pass.<br /><br />And still, we watch. We have no idea how the economy is controlled or who is making the decisions that will affect the lives of entire nations. We don't have a clue exactly why wars are fought, or even exactly what wars are being fought. We are blind to science, art, philosophy, and religion. we hardly bat an eye when we hear about industrial pollution on a biblical proportion, atrocities and genocide, or natural disasters wherein thousands of people die. But we know how things are going between Brad and Anjelina, who won last night's game, what soap star had sex with who, went into rehab, and what some loudmouth idiot with a talk show said that shocked and amused all of America the other day.<br /><br />This is what we have become; and Network warned us, every step of the way.<br /><br />But what I am impressed with is how the film exposes the horrifying economic and social realities of our time.<br />Ned Batty's brief scene in the conference room with Finch's Beale character has proven itself to be frighteningly accurate in its description of the disingenuous oligarchical tyranny we live under today. His explanation of the fact that there are no nations; only corporate entities, is exactly the world we live in - with the exception that the corporations are subservient to international banking cartels.<br /><br />No video collection should be without \\"Network\\": nobody can afford to ignore this film.<br /><br />For my own part, I refuse to permit television in my home.corporate entities, is exactly the world we live in - with the exception that the corporations are subservient to international banking cartels.      No video collection should be without \\"Network\\": nobody can afford to ignore this film.    For my own part, I refuse to permit television in my home.
B0000CDLA7|1.0|can you tell? i can! This album is not good.  <br />In a way it's a shame I don't like it - it's been touted as Dream Theater's heaviest yet, closest to thrash metal, furthest from prog-metal. I like heavy metal; I like crunchy riffs; I don't mind a lack of melody. I saw Dream Theater cover Metallica's Master of Puppets in its entirety at a concert in New York, and it was awe-inspiring. I was hoping they'd take that early-Metallica influence and do something cool with it. Instead, they've come up with their most tedious album since... uh... their last one. Sigh.  <br /> <br />Train of Thought is tedious in an entirely different way than Six Degrees of Inner Turbulence was. While it's chock full of similarly forgettable songs, they're forgettable mostly because they consist in large part of tired heavy metal riffs played really fast over. and. over. again. Keyboards play a much lesser role on this album; I never thought I'd miss the presence of Jordan Rudess (for a while I blamed him for Dream Theater's decline into suck-hood), but jesus! Anything to get Petrucci to quit showing off! Play Prog! <br /> <br />So, yeah - Train of Thought is basically devoid of memorable melodies (the ballad \\"Vacant\\" is laughable and extraneous); and although it contains a few riffs that are pretty potent, most of them sound recycled and, frankly, dull. And none of them are potent or interesting enough to sustain songs that almost invariably extend to ten exhausting minutes or more.  <br /> <br />This review might be a little overly harsh. It just pisses me off that a band I used to like so much, and a band with so much techincal talent, can put out such garbage. I mentioned on a message forum that maybe Dream Theater should just become a Metallica cover band instead of trying to write their own songs. These days, I'd like them much better that way. It's going to take a serious turnaround for these guys ever to get my attention again.  <br /> <br />Thank goodness I'm finished with this review, so I don't have to listen to this album ever again.

This song is supposedly about the loss of her grandmother. Now, that is nice and emotive, with lyrics like: <br />\\"The day you slipped away, was the day I found it won't be the same\\" are relatable, but the \\"na na, na na\\" of the opening entrance is laughable, and so juvenile and typical of the immaturity that peeps through every song she tries to pass off as deep and it it erases the seriousness of the subject matter. <br />This also seen on the song Together, a song about not feeling good about oneself when around another. This is a nice song, with  a good piano melody and rock atmosphere as well. She sings loudly: \\"Together, it doesnt feel right all, together we built a wall. That was a good chorus until\\"...holding hands we'll fall\\" and you just scream out: What?? This continues on in song after song. They all had a lot of potential. <br /> <br />In conclusion, Avril Lavigne screams about her independence and ability to do whatever she wants, but for a 19 year old, this is all pretty childish and simplistic things she is talking about(minus the song, Slipped Away which I feel is very sincere)-and that is fine, as many people can relate, but the music doesn't match it, and takes the album down a notch. I hope for a better Avril Lavigne record, as she matures.

B000063DFN|5.0|Iron Maiden achieves their best mix of impressive and mature instrumentation along with superb songwriting on this album. 0385491026|4.0|Margaret Atwood's \\"Cat's Eye\\" is a fascinating and immensely detailed work that deals with the interaction between adulthood and childhood, as well as the relationship between art, artists, and interpretation. The symbolic connections within the book are staggering, and unless it is read within a fairly short period, the reader is likely to forget some of the important symbols and miss key insights into Elaine's relationship with her childhood foil Cordelia.  <br /> <br />That said, this book is not without flaws. Like Ondaatje, Atwood suffers from a serious case of smug narrator syndrome. At times, I felt the urge to groan aloud at the sheer corniness of Elaine's musings, especially in the frame narrative of 1980s Toronto. However, Atwood's rendering of the protagonist's childhood traumas are captivating, and wonderfully excruciating to read. Nine-year-old girls have never seemed so insanely cruel, and the effect of this treatment on Elaine's adult life, as well as her art, is perfectly captured. Navigating art, feminism, psychology, aging, and memory, Atwood creates a kind of fractured bildungsroman in which lessons are forgotten and memories suppressed, only to resurface in the ambiguous medium of Elaine's painting.  <br /> <br />In terms of criticisms, I would agree with other reviewers that after Elaine's childhood, the narrative loses some steam. While the events of her later life are important to an understanding of Elaine's situation in the frame narrative, there is a sense that the events that allow us to fully understand Elaine as a character occur about mid-book. After that, things begin to drag a bit. Furthermore, the clichd narrative voice often gets in the way of connecting and identifying with the protagonist. However, it is interesting to see how the events and symbols of the narrator's childhood resurface in a complex web connecting the past and present.  <br /> <br />Overall, I would recommend this book, but with a warning to those who already have a bias against Atwood's style. If you give it a chance, I'm sure you'll enjoy it. But, if you already dislike Atwood, this book will not change your mind.
B000063DI9|5.0|I'm not sure why this album is criticized on the other reviews. The songwriting and creativity (not to mention orchestration) that go into this album surpass that of any other Maiden album.  There really isn't a single weak song on this album, but the \\"stand-outs\\" (if there can be stand-outs on a concept album) would have to be Moonchild, Clairvoyant, and Can I Play With Madness.  Listen to this several times; it will grow on you.  Not as catchy as some of Maiden's other work, but definitely their most musically complicated and refined effort.  Up the Irons!

B000059PPN|4.0|I have long been a Fulci fanatic and this film, \\"House By The Cemetery,\\" delivers the goods in spades. <br /> <br />The story is simple, if not altogether derivative. A young family moves from their cramped New York apartment into a spacious New England mansion. What sets this place apart from their previous abode, however, is the presence of the home's original owner, the detestable Dr. Freudstein. It would seem that he has been hiding in the home's shuttered basement for the last 100 years, picking off stray dwellers of the house and using their fluids and various other organs to sustain his own decomposing body. Sound far-fetched? Well, it should. But don't let that deter you. This is not \\"Rebecca From Sunnybrook Farm\\" or \\"Meet John Doe\\" we're talking about. It's a horror film with all the trademark gore and over-the-top violence we've come to expect from Lucio Fulci. Not high art by any stretch, but certainly never boring either. Definitely worth a purchase, especially if, like me, you happen to be a fan of this stuff. <br /> <br />The Anchor Bay DVD is absolutely first-rate with a pristine transfer and some cool theatrical/T.V. trailers.

B00004Y6O9|4.0|The first time I heard this, I was blown away, and played it countless times after that.      Most of the best songs are those you've already heard on radio play lists.  The less popular tracks are relatively weak, but should not be confused with filler.  Remember, this is 1978.  VHI was fresh, new, and experimental.  The style and guitar techniques were revolutionary, and had a great deal of influence on the best (and worst) of 80s metal.    It's important to take this album in historical context, before countless hair bands turned some great techniques and sounds into bad cliches. B000002JSN|5.0|I am not a die-hard Led Zeppelin fan. But I have come to have enormous respect for the quartet of Robert Plant, Jimmy Page, John Paul Jones, and John Bonham. I have come to realize that the efforts of a great work ethic have produced some of the stuff that legends are made of - and Led Zep takes the cake. Led Zeppelin's roots are in the Blues - thanks to lead singer Robert Plant and guitarist Jimmy Page who have always been a big fan of this type of music.   If you look at the early albums by Led Zeppelin, these roots are evident.   As their careers progressed, Led Zeppelin built a hard rock edge to their music on top of their blues music and soon were recognized as one of the most innovative bands in Rock.   One album that demonstrates such a sound is the 1975 double album by Led Zeppelin entitled \\"Physical Graffiti\\".   In a lot of ways, this was a landmark album and solidified what would become Led Zeppelin's legendary status. <br /> <br />This is a complete album by the quartet.  On every track you can hear the contributions - whether it's Robert Plant's vocals, Jimmy Page's guitar, John Paul Jones' Keyboards and Bass, or John Bonham's drums.  From a songwriting standpoint, all four members make contributions to the 15 track 2-CD set.  This is enhanced by the fact that Jimmy Page himself remastered this collection.    One interesting fact is that 7 tracks were recorded before 1974.   This implies that these are songs that never made it on to Led Zeppelin albums.  It's hard to believe that songs such as \\"The Rover\\", \\"Down By the Seaside\\", \\"Bron-Yr-Aur\\", \\"Houses of the Holy\\",  \\"Night Flight\\", \\"Boogie with Stu\\", and \\"Black Country Woman\\" are \\"leftovers\\". <br /> <br />Even the casual music fan is familiar with Led Zeppelin's \\"Stairway to Heaven\\".   This song was off their 1971 album known as \\"Led Zeppelin IV\\".   This song is generally considered the greatest Classic Rock song of all time.   There is no doubt that \\"Stairway to Heaven\\" is an all-time great song.  However, I feel Led Zeppelin have done two songs that are on the same level as \\"Stairway to Heaven\\" - and both of these songs are found on \\"Physical Graffiti\\".  The songs are \\"Trampled Under Foot\\" and \\"Kashmir\\".  \\"Trampled Under Foot\\" might not have the intricate lyrics that 'Stairway to Heaven\\" had, but this song is about the instrumentation.   This particular song has a feel for a jam session.   This song does have some blues roots - it is loosely based on Robert Johnson's 1936 blues song \\"Terraplane Blues\\".  However, make no mistake about it - this is an intense Zeppelin song through and through.  While Jimmy Page and John Bonham play guitar and drums respectively at the level you would expect, it is Robert Plant and John Paul Jones who are the real stars of this song.  Plant's passionate and intense vocals echo the intense instrumentation by the rest of the band.   As for John Paul Jones, his use of the keyboards are really what bring this song up a level - terrific.  Not to be judgmental, but as for the lyrics, references to car parts are used as metaphors for sexual references. <br /> <br />\\"Kashmir\\" is a very different song than both \\"Trampled Under Foot\\" and \\"Stairway to Heaven\\".  This is not a Blues-rooted song, but Zeppelin innovation through and through. At the same time, this song doesn't have the feel of a jam session, but in some ways has some middle-eastern orchestral qualities.  In a lot of ways, this was experimental musical territory that Led Zeppelin was embarking on. \\"Kashmir\\" actually refers to an area of land that is disputed by Pakistan, India, and China.   This song was actually written by Robert Plant as he was traveling through North Africa in the Sahara desert (which ironically is still a far distance from Kashmir, but Plant envisioned himself driving all the way from Morocco to Kashmir).   The song has a distinct middle-eastern flair and basically gives you the feeling of traveling in that part of the world.  Once again - each member of Zeppelin: Plant, Page, Jones, and Bohnam all make major contributions to the sound.  However - Plant and Jones rise to the occasion again.  Plant demonstrates some terrific vocal ranges, while Jones' Bass, Keyboards, and String arrangements are some of the best ever heard. <br /> <br />There are other terrific tracks on this collection.   The opening two tracks, \\"Custard Pie\\" and \\"The Rover\\" have their roots in blues.  \\"Custard Pie\\" is one of those songs that takes a while to get into. You can definitely see how many hard rockers followed the innovations set by Zeppelin when you listen to this track.   \\"The Rover\\" starts out with some Country-Blues sound, but then progresses to a hard rock sound.  It has a terrific instrumental opening.  Another good blues track is the retro sounding \\"Boogie With Stu\\".  While the final track \\"Sick Again\\" has a blues sound, it almost sounds like a prototype for the Heavy Metal sound. <br /> <br />Another very good song is \\"Night Flight\\" - this song often gets overlooked, but it another complete effort by the quartet - more great keyboards by John Paul Jones.  Other highlights include the instrumental \\"Bron-Yr-Aur\\", the classic \\"The Wanton Song\\" (featuring great drums by Bonham), and \\"Ten Years Gone\\".  Experimentation is alive and well on this collection.  You will hear this in the slightly psychedelic \\"In the Light\\".  Another overlooked, yet what I would consider an experimental song is \\"Down By the Seaside\\".   I call this song Led Zeppelin's experiment with some Hawaiian sounds - great stuff and great vocals by Plant.  <br /> <br />While the songwriting and production credits are included, I am very disappointed there were no lyrics included in this collection.   The only \\"extra\\" is you get in the liner notes is the \\"where\\" and \\"when\\" this song was recorded.  Overall, this is perhaps the finest collection by Led Zeppelin that they have released.  Highly recommended.
B00001OH7P|5.0|<br />Although it is considered a concept album of sorts, it doesn't get bogged down in themes or complex stories.  It didn't even occur to me that it was a concept album, until someone mentioned it.  That's part of the beauty: you can enjoy the songs as songs. <br /> <br />The production is crisp and high-quality, but not overdone.  Despite the sci-fi theme, it has a good balance of dirty rock-and-roll crunch, so that it stays down-to-earth, and not too geeky, artsy, or spaced-out (\\"Suffragette City\\" is a good example). <br /> <br />If you get this album, it's worth checking out the lyrics online, if they're not included with the cd. It does not sound like five accomplished adults with a rich mold-breaking musical catalogue to their credit. They had great song structures that were progressive and made sense but now it seems like a string of poor interpretations of progressive song structuring. I got tired of the non sequitur changes and the lack of any true groove. One thing I've always loved about them was their ability to transition and change time signatures but there is a way to do that right which requires finesse and maturity. That is, for some reason, absent here. And where did Myung go? Did he take a vacation? Because I didn't hear any of that great bass work that so grandly complimented their previous material. Cometo think of it I didn't here many harmonies and melodies at all. Nothing. I don't care how difficult you make it to execute it's just noise. Anyone can make noise and they do.  <br /> <br />Between reviews I've read and people I have spoken with I have noticed that it has been common to justify the sound by simply saying it's of a different musical genre. Well, I'm sorry to break it to you but that is simply not enough. The prinicples of music do not change from one genre to another. What makes something good and relevant is consistent, regardless of simplicity and complexity. \\"Train of Thought\\" was an excruciating letdown that I hope Dream Theater doesn't deal me again. But I gotta tell you, because of the trend displayed by their last two studio releases, I'm going to be far more cautious about my purchase of the upcoming.

B00005JMAH|2.0|This new chronicle in the Harry Potter sequence is nowhere near worthy of the rosy ratings of most reviews because of two simple reasons. <br /> <br />The first of these is the acting.  I feel that the actors preformed their parts well, but I have several major qualms with the new director, Alfonso Cuaron, about his choices for the portrayal of the characters.  The first major flop was Dumbledore.  The actor played the part well, and retained the look and sound of the old Dumbledore, but the lines and intonation were appalling.  The literary purpose of Dumbledore is as a source of safety and comfort for Harry, but this movie lost all of that.  The primary problem was that Dumbledore lost all of his appeal to the audience because he no longer retains that indelible Dumbledore quality of warmth.  He was brisk, snappish, and terse in his addresses to the students, and this is a serious departure from the caring and deep Dumbledore we met in the first two movies.  The theatrical lighting also enhanced this new image: the first two movies had a great deal of yellow and orange light, while the color swatch for this was more toward the cooler colors such as blue.  The other acting difficulty is apparent by even looking at a poster for the movie; Harry is no longer the central character.  After seeing this film, I came away with the impression that Hermione had achieved dominance in the film titled Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.  This is but one of the two major reasons that this movie is barely worthy of two stars out of five. <br /> <br />The other reason that this movie disappoints me is the content.  While I have to admit that all of the sequences shown in the movie were very good, it is what is not shown that is the most distressing.  The Harry Potter books have a unique charm resulting from Rowling's phenomenal ability to characterize, the intense reality of the world she weaves, and her ability to build a plot rich with intrigues out of minor supporting details.  And her characterizations often occur alongside her sublime plot details, which only add to her skill as a writer.  But this movie only barely manages to capture the world she wrought in The Prisoner of Azkaban, and loses the plot entirely.  Too many things were left out, many of which left viewers puzzled.  For example, when Lupin revealed to Potter that he knew how to use the Marauder's Map, none of the characters batted an eyelash.  Moreover, the entire subplot about Harry's father was omitted; this included who \\"Moony, Wormtail, Padfoot, Prongs\\" were, the fact that they were all Animagi, or wizards who can transform into animals, or why Harry's patronus was a stag.  I feel that this is likely connected to Harry no longer being a central character in the movie bearing his name.  Overall, I feel that this movie strays dangerously close to what Christopher Coloumbus alluded to wanting to do with the Harry Potter series, take all the action sequences from all the books, and combine them into a single movie. <br /> <br />In conclusion, I feel that this film seriously undermines the characters and mutilates the plot.  By changing the character focus and leaving out central story elements, this movie not only poorly portrays this book, but also changes things so considerably that it will be a huge hurdle to recover from these blunders in the Harry Potter movies to come. <br />

But \\"Damnation\\" is no death metal album.  Instead it sheds signatures of that genre and concentrates on what I think Opeth really does best: the textures within the music.   This album is incredible. Listen to \\"Closure\\" for example; first time through you enjoy the interesting eastern influences of it.  Second time through you catch what the song is about and your heart skips a beat.  I'd say that rather than losing the constrasting elements, they've fused them. This is powerful stuff, give it at least two listens to really begin to feel it.

He seems to perform almost magical stunts on several occasions, e.g. causing Carlotta's croaking, disappearing from Masquerade ball in a puff of smoke, shooting fireballs, gesturing the portcullis up, and the last scene disappearing act. We always felt like the Phantom had some supernatural element about him.    Interestingly, ALW and Shumacher take pains to reveal the Phantom going through his machinations: Locking Christine's door, Meg revealing the sliding mirror, dropping through the floor from Masquerade ball where Raoul follows, and most obviously, the sword fight that he loses! Quite a difference from the stage version.  Then, at the end, they bring back the magic. Had they ended with the Phantom simply escaping through a shattered mirror, it would have been a huge letdown. But the cemetery scene, with sad, oboe-tinged music, and the rose w/ring, obviously placed there recently, was the perfect ending.         Very much a worthy adaptation.

We have to realize that writing is an art form and that Anne Rice manages to tell us a tale about ideas we are already familiar with (such as God and the Devil) and yet Memoch the Devil challenges these ideas and simultaneously makes us fall in love with them. I think that readers have never been so fully given a character such as Lestat, who epitomizes human nature and meshes it with his vampire existence perfectly. Personally, I have never been able to relate to a character so much. As Lestat questions all that is presented to him, you will question it too. I liked Memnoch more than God in this book. Memnoch provided a perfect sort of antagonist to this story and to Lestat's ongoing story. Memnoch skillfully challenges Lestat in a way that only the Devil could. And maybe the Devil IS the only suitable challenger for Lestat...Memnoch the Devil is anything but disappointing. It is creative and smart and beautiful in every sense of the word. Anne Rice fans will not feel disappointed. Memnoch the Devil truly makes the reader become completely engulfed this story's wonderful creativity.

B000002KYH|3.0|Rod Stewart is a great live performer, but this 1982 live album does not do him justice. Though there are some occasional shades of greatness, \\"Absolutely Live\\" falls flat for the most part.<br /><br />As one reviewer pointed out, it's the first half of the album where the problems lie. Rod stumbles his way through inadequate performances of \\"Passion\\" and \\"Sweet Little Rock And Roller\\". \\"Hot Legs\\" is good but not great. \\"Tonight's The Night (Gonna Be Alright\\" and \\"You're In My Heart (The Final Acclaim\\") are simply horrifying.<br /><br />The second half of the album is where the bright spot lies. The performance of \\"Young Turks\\" works well without the synthesized instruments and such, transforming into a barroom rocker. Rod's megahits \\"Maggie May\\" and \\"Da Ya Think I'm Sexy\\" sound as fresh and vibrant as ever, while \\"Gasoline Alley\\", \\"Sailing\\" and \\"I Don't Want To Talk About It\\" are emotional powerhouses. Finally, the closing \\"Stay With Me\\" with Kim Carnes and Tina Turner is the best song on the whole album. the only bad song here is \\"Tear It Up\\".<br /><br />Overall, this album would make a good addition to your Rod collection, but by no means is this an essential purchase. If you want to see a truly great Rod Stewart concert\\", get the \\"Storytellers\\", \\"It Had To Be You...\\" and \\"...Royal Albert Hall\\" dvds. Those are truly great concerts.

B000002WUD|5.0|Though by no means his most successful period, the last seven yeats of Elvis Presley's life (1970-77) were arguably when he made his finest work. This five cd boxed set is the best representation of all of his best work from the 1970s'.<br /><br />Discs 1 and 2 contain all the singles he released during this period. In addition to his final two top ten singles from this era (\\"The Wonder Of You\\" and the scorching \\"Burning Love\\"), there's some less fondly remembered singles such as \\"Where Did They Go Lord\\", \\"Until It's Time For You To Go\\", \\"I've Got A Thing About You Baby\\" and \\"Hurt\\". Also, most of the b - sides are here, so great tracks like \\"Patch It Up\\", the haunting \\"Life\\", and \\"We Can Make The Morning\\" get their due.<br /><br />Disc 3 contains the hits from 1970 to 1971. Though it's a relatively brief period, there's a wealth of great stuff here, including \\"Just Pretend\\", \\"Funny How Time Slips Away\\", \\"I Washed My Hands In Muddy Water\\" and \\"Snowbird\\". The whole disc is great, but these are just some of the best numbers.<br /><br />Disc 4 contains material from 1971 to 1976. This cd contains a ton of great stuff. Among the highlights: a chilling unreleased cover of \\"My Way\\", the funky \\"I've Got A Feelin' In My Body\\", the mellow \\"You Asked Me To\\", the eerie \\"Good Time Charlie's Got The Blues\\", the upbeat \\"Talk About The Good Times\\" and his stunning version of \\"Danny Boy\\". This is the best disc.<br /><br />Disc 5 is concert material, which is excellent. Among the highlights are energetic performances of \\"Walk A Mile In My Shoes\\", \\"Let It Be Me\\". \\"A Big Hunk O'Love\\" and \\"Unchained Melody\\", as well as some great rehearsal recordings.<br /><br />This is an amazing look at Elvis's final years. Definitely worth owning.

B000001ELL|3.0|The good points:<br /><br />(1)  Ace Frehley has some very strong music here.  Even his cover of the Rolling Stones' \\"2000 Man\\" has become his own song here.  His best track, though, is \\"Hard Times\\", a sadly overlooked autobiography of his time on the streets, with a strong hook and blazing guitar work.<br /><br />(2)  Paul Stanley's vocals.  The man has a strong voice, and he uses it well here.  The strangest one is the extreme falsetto on \\"I Was Made for Lovin' You\\".  Pick hit for me is probably the underrated \\"Magic Touch\\", where Paul's voice stretches up and down the scale but flows at this dance-ballad's pace.<br /><br />(3) Gene's guitar on \\"X-Ray Eyes\\".  (Yes, it's Gene, not Ace).  Dark, moody, and fits the song very well.<br /><br />(4)  Peter Criss's voice on \\"Dirty Livin'\\".  Peter has a good voice for this type of driving beat.<br /><br />(5)  \\"Save Your Love\\".  Written for Peter, by Ace, about Peter's divorce from Lydia, his first wife.  Possibly some of Ace's best work on this album.<br />Bad points:<br /><br />(1)  TOO MANY SYNTHS.  The keyboards drown out the guitars on a lot of the songs.  Take a lesson from early Queen, guys-- lose the synths.<br /><br />(2)  \\"It's easy\\" should not be a reason to write a song.  Paul found \\"I Was Made...\\" very easy to write, but he wasted his talent here.  His solo album was a TON better than some of his work here.<br /><br />(3) The \\"I'm Gene and I want to **** you\\" thing was played out with a lot of his earlier stuff, especially around 1978.<br /><br />Bottom line:  this album was marketed by the right band, to the wrong crowd, for the wrong reasons, and some of the best material on it went ignored.  You'll really like the pop stuff if you're 12 and haven't heard their better stuff.  Otherwise, they have much better albums than this one.

630521610X|5.0|\\"Scream\\", released in 1996, is a great horror film that stars Neve Campbell, Courtney Cox (now Cox-Arquette), David Arquette, Jamie Kennedy, Drew Berrymore, Skeet Ulrich, Matthew Lillard, and others.  This film pays homage to many horror film classics that many horror film fanatics never forget.  Two sequels proceed.  Its release started a new frenzy of horror film fans.  It encouraged its audiences to watch the classics that influenced this film.  This later became Wes Craven's highest grossing film to date.  It received critical acclaim, including a consideration for an Oscar nomination for Best Original Screenplay (which was overlooked).      \\"Scream\\" desplicts a group of people in a town that is terrorized by a \\"serial killer\\" whose obsession with horror films goes too far.  He, she, or they call the intended victim, alters their voice through a machine, flirts with them, threatens them, and attacks them.  The police force's only lead to the killer's identity is a ghost mask.  Sidney Prescott (Campbell) seems to be the main target to this killer.  Does it connect to the brutal slaying of her mother a year before?  Does the killer want revenge, or does the killer want to play copycat?  Until the questions are answered, everybody is a suspect.  And those who break any of the horror film rules become a target.    Director Wes Craven certainly knows the true meaning of horror as he combines these films into this film, yet, fitting wonderfully.  He doesn't spoof any of them.  Rather, he creates his own horror film that is truly chilling.  He occassionally includes non-horror projects that fit the film well, including \\"The Ricki Lake Show\\".  Meanwhile, he adds the occassional teen humor that relates well to that age group.  Despite branching off other horror films, his creativity is expressed greatly as in his past films.  He takes the typical horror film traditions, mixes them, and makes them his own.  He makes every chase scene a roller coaster ride, every suspicious scene suspenseful, and every bloody violent scene intense.    Horror film commemorations include \\"Friday, the 13th\\", \\"Halloween\\", \\"Carrie\\", \\"The Exorcist\\", and his own \\"Nightmare On Elm Street\\".  Wes Craven plays a cameo as the janitor \\"dressed as\\" Freddy Krueger.  Through these various homage scenes, the main storyline of people being stalked by the killer is never distracted.  Meanwhile, he gives this film its own legacy beyond the now-infamous ghost mask.  While many other previous blockbuster films have tried paying homage to other films like it, this is the first that has succeeded in high quality.    Through this storyline, the actors finely express the crutial points of the film that make it more entertaining.  They scream wonderfully, they express their terror wonderfully, and they offer their own sense of humor through the perfect scenes.  Campbell expresses the terrorizing theme the highest while stretching Jamie Lee Curtis's legacy as Laurie Strode from \\"Halloween\\".  Cox and Arquette offer the sense of humor the most as an annoying news reporter and a police officer.  The actor or actors who play the killer or the killers offer their terrorizing moments greatly that make their character or characters more chilling.    \\"Scream\\" begins an unforgattable fine trilogy that will hold its position in film history for a long time.  Those interested in this trilogy must watch this edition first.  Otherwise, they will not understand the storyline.  This will surely continue pleasing its audiences as it has since its release.

B0000CDLA7|1.0|It is very difficult for me to give this album less than four stars, but I know that deep down, the album as a whole just doesn't \\"do it\\" for me. I am the farthest thing from a metalhead that you can find. I listen to Shostakovich. Therefore I am a HUGE Yes fan, and I love all of the other classic Prog rock bands; Genesis, Pink Floyd, ELP, Supertramp etc. I had heard great things about Dream Theater, that they were the best Prog Metal band there is, and also the best \\"third tier\\" prog band. This was the only DT album that my local music store had, so I bought it, after reading the awesome reviews on this website. I experienced reactions that were more mixed than all other reactions I have ever experienced. Commence track by track review now: \\"As I Am\\" - Not bad. The introduction is a great way to start an album. A shimmering keyboard chord evaporates into an awesome distorted guitar line, followed by loud and slow guitar chords. Then the main body of the song begins, and it speeds along fairly well. \\"This Dying Soul\\" - Ugggh! What a terrible song! There is no trace of prog in this number. Being a Shostakovich fan, I can't take more than one minute of this. It almost single handedly removed a star from my rating! \\"Endless Sacrifice\\" - I like the acoustic bits, and I hate everything else. \\"Honour thy Father\\" - This is very much like \\"TDS\\" to me, but not quite as bad. By now you may be thinking, \\"He hates this album, where did 3 stars come from?\\" Read on. \\"Vacant\\" - A nice (if short) ballad of desperation, in which a man loses a loved one. Probably a daughter, judging by the corresponding photograph in the Storm Thergousten (sp?) booklet. This acts as a prologue to the emotions expressed in \\"Stream of Consciousness\\". \\"Stream of Consciousness\\" - WOW. This lengthyish instrumental is the high point of the album for me. So many musical ideas are packed together in one enormously technical and emotional song. I always have to move when I listen to this song. I usually do air keyboards, as this is my home instrument. Jordan Rudess's brief keyboard excursions make me cry. Great guitar and drums as well. \\"In the Name of God\\" - Another OK track. The longest on the album, and with the best lyrics. It talks about how people bend what the Bible says and exploit fanatics for their own gain. The Latin bit is really cool, and this track has some great acoustic guitar. Now. Why 1 1/2 stars? Because I just heard Images and Words. Every song on the album surpasses the first four tracks on this album, but none of it can come close to the last two. This is a good place to start if you want to get into DT, as it will let you know if you like the \\"Six Degrees\\" era, which I have heard is very heavy; or the \\"Scenes From a Memory\\" era, which is brilliant prog metal.

B0002F7I9Y|4.0|Ray Charles was a first-rate musician. He could make music! But this CD, in general, is not a joy to hear. First (through no fault of his own--he was very sick, after all), Charles' voice sounds very weak and strained here. One can still hear evidence of his outstanding talent, but it is very diminished. Second, most of the song selections were not well-advised. I love James Taylor, for example, but not that song, and certainly not in duet with Ray Charles. Similar comment can be made about many of the other songs and singers. Two or three of the tracks are excellent, however, particularly Charles' respective duets with Bonnie Raitt, Van Morrison, and Johnny Mathis. In my opinion, those three tracks alone are worth the purchase price (while most of the others I probably will skip in future). Also (for you audiophiles), the recording-quality varies from track to track; sometimes it is very good, but mostly it is merely adequate. <br />

B0007TKNIS|5.0|This was a brilliant version of Phantom of the Opera. I have never seen the actual stage presentation of the musical, so this was a treat to watch in on the big screen. Like many of the other reviewers, I felt like this adaptation of the musical pulls off the big screen feel that this work should have.  <br /> <br />Another reason this version thrives is that the movie did not diminish or impede LeRoux's original novel. This could have been another lame attempt by Hollywood to take a story from a novel and \\"dumb\\" it down, adding unnecessary plot details and overdone scenes. Thankfully that didn't happen, and the gothic/ horror feel is depicted successfully.  <br /> <br />The singing is superb and I felt like the movie was well cast. Emmy Rossum exerts a successful job as Christine Daae and Gerard Butler does as well also as the Phantom. With the way the film is produced and directed, it is not hard to \\"get into\\" the head of specific characters.  <br /> <br />Sometimes it is the small aspects that make movies a grade better than the rest. The way the producers used the black and white screen to flash ahead to another time at the movie's outset, and then periodically go back to this, was uniquely satisfying, and helps the story along. It also made the transitions back into LeRoux's story even more effective. Also, the cinematography and visual effects aid in exemplifying the essential themes of the story: love, hate, jealousy, inner beauty, despair, isolation, hope. These all come forth in the grand chandelier scene, the cemetery scene with Christine, the isolation of the Phantom in his chambers, and the magnificent opera scenes.  <br /> <br />Finally, there is a successful transition from Broadway musical to movie. This one does live up to the hype.  <br />

B0007GAERG|5.0|Mariah has been one of the most impressive and unbelievable artists within the past few decades. There's no question to it. Simply, \\"It's Like That\\". The vocalist who gained superstardom with the strength of her 5-Octave voice, I have seen a lack of quality in Mariah's music since 1999. What was the cause of this? I would bet that it was because of competition of other new mainstream artists such as Britney Spears who created sex appeal as one of their main strategy factors. Britney's music was all incorporated with sex appeal, which brought a new generation of teenaged pop singers. Some remained in the scene, and some faded away in an instant. This entire teen-pop generation intimidated Mariah's current record company who at the time was - Sony Columbia Records. Investigatively, they were forcing many of their artists to incorporate sex appeal and follow the manners of Britney Spears - who's methods actually WERE working at the time around the late 90's and early 2000's (The ...Baby One More Time and Oops!... I Did It Again era). Just look at the CD cover of \\"Daydream\\" (one of Mariah's best albums from 1995) and compare it to a more recent \\"Rainbow\\" (The cover depicts her in her underwear). Obviously, the sex appeal has been magnified to what it was before. Columbia seemed to have concentrated more on sex appeal and less on musical quality and artistry unfortunately... These failed attempts caused her to move to Virgin Records - causing an even bigger flop of 2001's \\"Glitter\\" and then moving to Island of Universal's UMG and releasing another failure - \\"Charmbracelet\\". Finally after her past 6 years of unfulfilled attempts, Mariah has returned with \\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\" which debuted at #1, certifying itself as gold within just 2 weeks. The start-off single \\"It's Like That\\" proves that \\"Mimi\\" can include both an R&B club beat and also demonstrate powerful vocal ability in one track. The follow-up single \\"We Belong Together\\" is a sugar-sweet ballad which showcases many of Mariah's powerful vocals and pushingly persuades the listener to comprehend how powerful of a vocalist Mariah really is -- something today's shallow music industry is obviously lacking. The next big stand-out is \\"Mine Again\\", a slower-tempo track really showcases how powerful Mariah's voice still retains at the mature age of 35. \\"Get Your Number\\" featuring Jermaine Dupri is a big club or upbeat standout track in the album -- though I find that it refers to far too many materialistic refences. For example, she pleads of having \\"A house in capri and my own G4 and the Benz with the doors that lift up from the floor\\" and unforgetably, \\"A pip penthouse with a sick hot-tub\\". These references obviously refer to how she is attempting to also be favorable to younger audiences as well as older A/C listeners. The last mentionnable tracks on this cut are \\"Circles\\" and \\"Joy Ride\\", once again demonstrating the powerful vocals which Mariah still retains - 15 years into her superstardom. Mariah's true success secret is how she now simultaneaously appeals to polytheistic audiences - with her R&B hooks loved by the younger \\"hip\\" teenagers and her more relaxed and powerful AC ballads favored by older adult audiences. Though Mariah's voice has finally returned and is very powerful, it is lacking something that it had in 1993's \\"Music Box\\" and 1995's \\"Daydream\\". But I've got to cut her some slack - She's 35 years old and no longer 20!  <br /> <br />Mariah's success and talent is simply a fact of life. It's simply \\"Like That\\".  <br />My days of waiting for another worthy Mariah album is over... <br />...Finally!

They built a nest of rocks like all the other couples and sat on the rocks hoping for a chick like all the other penguins.  With a little help, they ended up with their own special family.  What a wonderful way to introduce children to the concept of different types of families!  The love they have for one another is so touching and natural.  It proves that these bonds form quite naturally and that the love shared is just as valid as in the traditional family.
B00006CXSS|5.0|Band of Brothers will remain one of the greatest World War II films ever made for years to come. From Normandy on D-Day to Hitler's Eagles Nest, this film follows Easy Company, 2nd Battalion, 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment throughout it's WWII experience. The characters are true to life and offer an inside look at what American Paratroopers dealt with during the war. Special effects and outstanding cinematography contribute to making this film an awesome visual experience. After a dozen or more times watching this film, I can't get enough.

Goldblum's monologue goes on to suggest that the almost perfect human - possibly represented by \\"Powder\\" (Jeremy) himself - would evolve through eons of love, understanding, and the 100% use of his or her brain (as opposed to the apparently less than 10% most of us are using now) to the point that he or she would no longer require the human body and would literally become the purest form of that human energy - as \\"Conversations with God\\" author Neale Donald Walsch might call it, a living flame finally prepared to interact lovingly with other living flames (not to mention God) without fear.         Goldblum further quotes Einstein later in the movie even more poignantly:  \\"It has become appallingly clear that our technology has surpassed our humanity.\\"  However, with its heartfelt direction by Victor Salva, superb acting by Goldblum, Flanery, Mary Steenburgen and Lance Henriksen, other-worldly photography by Jerry Zielinski, and J.S. Bach-level score by the late great Jerry Goldsmith, POWDER is proof positive that sometimes our humanity DOES surpass our technology, even in Hollywood.

Still, people should stop comparing this to discovery and look at the album for what it is. Its not perfect, but its not in any way worse than their other albums. B000929AJQ|4.0|Pretty Hate Machine was the only NIN CD I liked immediately.  Okay, I knew upon first hearing it that CLOSER was a classic, and I did warm up to Downward Spiral faster than, say, Broken, but I had to listen to The Fragile maybe six or seven times before it got me (then, of course, it was all I listened to for months).  My point is that NIN is not like any other rock group - you basically know what Aerosmith's next album is gonna sound like.  Ditto DMB.  But Trent makes music that makes sense to him at the time, regardless of what formula used to sell.  Pretend it's visual art: why do the same Campbell's soup painting every year for the rest of your life?  Even if it got you rich, what if you felt like sculpting something, even if it doesn't sell to the public?  Art is about fulfilling an artist's original ideas and conceptions, business is about making money.  (Think about that when you're standing in line at the next summer sequel.)  How do I judge With Teeth?  I was happy that \\"Deep\\" was more of a return to an earlier style, but loved his acoustic album \\"Still\\" and With Teeth is a nice amalgum of the two.  Are there flaws?  Yep.  An odd running order?  Yep.  Do a few songs seem to not fit?  Yeah - but remember, this was originally a project called \\"bleedthrough\\" that was to be a whole album of songs with no chords (think of ninety minutes of \\"WithTeeth,\\" and \\"Beside You In Time.....\\") and seemingly changed course at the very end - who knows if that record would have been the Pretty Hate Machine version of The Fragile?  It takes a few listens, but once you hit Every Day Is Exactly The Same, you've got a great album on your hands.
B0000CDLA7|2.0|For me this album represents a big decline in the quality of writing from Dream Theater. The songs although chock full of heavy riffs, unisons and time sig shifts seem to lack any direction and to my ears end up sounding like a collection of riffs. The lack of distinct clear melodic hooks is also very disapointing...I've always enjoyed Dream Theater above other prog/metal bands because of their ability to fuse interesting harmonic ideas, blistering technicality with soaring melodies but here, the melodic aspects are sadly missing. Technically the playing is immaculate as always, John Petrucci (Guitars) really goes for the throat on this disc (personally I prefer his more melodic playing). Everything is tight and accurate and the production is great - the bass is more audible than previous releases. If you like your prog on the heavier side of the spectrum theres lots to interest you here, otherwise you may be well advised to check out some of the bands earlier releases - \\"Images and Words\\" or \\"Six Degrees of Inner Turbulance\\".

B0006U4UAU|4.0|First things first; following the motions of many other reviewers here, LCD Soundsystem earns big bonus points for including a second disc of earlier singles to accompany this 2005 debut album.<br /><br />With that said, the new material is quality stuff in its own right. It's a mixed bag with some nice surprises, and its share of letdowns. \\"Daft Punk...\\" and \\"Great Release\\" aren't nearly half as good as they are made out to be. I don't think there is really one appropriate genre actually. Some of the tracks sound like what is considered \\"house\\" music. I'm also unsure of what sounds something has to consist of to be granted that label, but I suppose this record partially fits the description. Then you have the track \\"Never As Tired,\\" which brings to mind for me, an experimental Syd Barrett flavour. Certainly not \\"house.\\"<br /><br />The first disc on its own merits a 3-star-rating, but the singles disc kicks it up a notch. The entire disc is excellent material, all of which is mind-bending. \\"Beat Connection\\" and \\"Give It Up\\" are on opposite ends of the spectrum, the former being very drawn out with building, acidic beats; the latter being an all out assault, but both fitting into the mix seamlessly.<br /><br />\\"Losing My Edge\\" is just an undeniably fantastic track. I am at a loss for words describing it... it just remains painfully good every time I listen to it. Both versions of \\"Yeah\\" could be the best pieces of music I've heard over the last five years. The Crass version reaches over nine minutes, and the Pretentious version almost stretches out to twelve. Yet they both hold your attention for the duration. \\"Yeah (Crass)\\" is definitely the more danceable version, and will be keeping heavy rotation among my current playlists.<br /><br />Overall, the spotty first disc prevents this album from being a classic. But between the worthwhile stuff found there, plus the duration of the second disc, LCD Soundsystem is well worth the price of admission./> <br />Overall, the spotty first disc prevents this album from being a classic. But between the worthwhile stuff found there, plus the duration of the second disc, LCD Soundsystem is well worth the price of admission.

B00005JNBQ|4.0|Granted, this \\"revenge of the nerds of the millennium\\" is NOT for everybody, but I'm certainly one of those who find it funny as hell, and a tad charming. <br /> <br />For one thing, it takes time to warm up to this film. A lot of really strange vignettes happen in the first half hour that really don't make a lot of sense (our man throwing a toy with a string on it out of a school bus window and watching it drag along the road, a farmer shooting a cow (offscreen, thank goodness) for no apparant reason, Napoleon and Pedro's female friend shyly attempting to sell Napoleon some junk, etc). Plus, the actors playing Napoleon and his best friend Pedro Sanchez look WAY too old to be in high school. <br /> <br />But after you sit through this with some patience, the \\"story\\" begins to hang together. Bascially, it's a really SWEET (as Napoleon would say) story of the bonds of friendship being established among social outcasts. Also, it's chock full of wild catch phrases (such as the title of this review) with deadpan delivery that you can't help but shout out at repeated viewings. <br /> <br />Of course, there are bound to be ultrasensitive over PC need-to-get-a-life types who will criticize this movie for some ethnic stereotyping. Here I refer to Pedro Sanchez himself and his admittedly hackneyed Mexican-American accent, Pedro's lowriding (apparently) gangbanging cousins, and LaFawnda, the Detroit ghetto queen who Napoleon's brother falls in love with over the internet. As an African-American myself, I would have to say that this is not \\"Soul Plane\\" or the \\"Frito Bandito.\\" These characters are likeable people who, beneath the superficial cultural differences, anybody could relate to. Plus, LaFawnda (unlike the overtly ghetto fabulous/slum pitiful sisters of UPN and BET) has a touch of class about herself and a good heart (in her advice to Napoleon in particular). As for Pedro, he's a fish out of water that is also a very sympathetic character. <br /> <br />But overall, anyone who has ever felt like they've been on the outside of humanity looking in (and who hasn't felt that way from time to time?) could realte to at least something this film, so see it. There's a reason why so many people are wearing all those \\"Vote For Pedro\\" t-shirts. After all, you too could drink whole milk if you wanted to! (see the movie and you'll get that last line).

B0006GAI6Y|1.0|The Japanese version of this movie falls into the comedic category of a \\"Manners Comedy.\\" In a Manners Comedy, the characters are so super-concerned with what other people will think about them that they do crazy things to avoid being \\"found out.\\" This is set up beautifully in the opening narrative of the original, where the narrator makes the statements about Japanese culture and reserve, how couples will not show affection in public, and that to be caught actually enbracing a stranger in public would be \\"beyond embarassing.\\" <br /> <br />The script of the original has a beautiful balance of characters who are \\"safe\\" and characters who are \\"dangerous.\\" The charming older lady teacher is \\"safe\\" and the lead character naturally gravitates to her. The overweight and unfiltered \\"fat lady dancer\\" character is \\"dangerous\\" and leads, at all points in the movie, to embarrassment. Yet in the end, she too is a supportive friend and there is a wonderful mutual acceptance among ALL the characters. This is part of the charm of the movie - the notion that in the end, dancing promotes civilized, harmonious interaction. The characters are ALL exposed in the end, and that creates a caring and a bond between them. <br /> <br />The original is a very sweet, beautiful little movie. <br /> <br />Now to this movie: <br /> <br />1. Richard Gere should never have been cast. It is simply  impossible to accept him as a man who feel overwhelmingly trapped in his mundane life.  <br /> <br />2. Jennifer Lopez should never have been cast. She doesn't have the substance required for the role. For one thing, she is a terrible dancer. For another, she lacks the polish of someone who has been trained to compete at the world level in such a \\"sophisticated\\" endeavor. The role requires someone like Audrey Hepburn or Ingrid Bergman. Instead we get \\"barfly\\" <br /> <br />3. All the fundamental conflicts and goals that drive the plot  in the movie are missing in this version. In the original movie, the main character's melancholy was brought on by a recent home purchase. There is a vitally important scene in the original movie that was left out of the remake. In the original, the Stanley Tucci character has a conversation with the Richard Gere character in which he praises the latter for being \\"a big success - you're moving up.\\" In response, the Richarad Gere character says \\"I had to mortgage my life to the firm to pay for it.\\" This is a fantastically critical line because it tells the audience, as early as possible, what the main character's conflict is - he feels TRAPPED. He worked all his life to buy this house and now that he has it, it feels like a ball and chain. In the same scene, the Stanley Tucci character is ridiculed by his co-workers. He too feels trapped in a life that is not right for him, too. Yet because of Japanese reserve and manners and traditions, both feel guilty - they must \\"do their duty\\" and live their lives as others tell them life should be lived. <br /> <br />In America, the fundamental conflict that drives the whole movie really doesn't translate very well, does it? In America we all can already do pretty much anything we want. To translate the plot to Chicago would require subtlety and intelligence. This director is apparently devoid of either. <br /> <br />In the Japanese version, the wife character is TOTALLY dependent on her husband. This is important. In the American version, the wife character seems completely independent. If she loses Richard Gere, it's not life or death - she gets a very healthy alimony and immediately moves on to someone else. In Japan, divorced women cannot so easily remarry. The stakes for the wife are much higher in that movie. And since it is a Manners Comedy, she is too embarrassed to confront her husband directly. Instead, she hires a private detective. This makes no sense in the American version. <br /> <br />4. A fundamental question of the original movie is, \\"is the relationship between the lead and thedancer adulterous?\\" What drives the Richard Gere character to the J-Lo character? How can we forgive him for doing it? <br /> <br />In the original, we know the lead character is TRAPPED. (\\"mortgaged his life to the firm\\"). He explains to the    Stanley Tucci character that he got married and had a child    almost before he knew what he was doing. He feels he SHOULD be happy - he has accomplished all of his goals - yet something    is missing. And he doesn't know what it is. <br /> <br />When he sees the beautiful young woman looking out the window,  he doesn't just say to himself \\"hubba hubba! what a dish\\" and    resolve to bed her. Instead, he is drawn to her because she    appears to be \\"trapped\\" too. She is like a beautiful bird in    a cage, looking out at the world. She wants to fly away. He    can sense this. He wonders why - she is so beautiful, how can    she not be happy? Why is she like me? Why is it that we both    have everything society tells us we need to be happy, yet we    are not happy?  <br /> <br />In the original, you can get the gist of this because of the    way the plot is set-up, and because of the excellent use of    the camera, and because of the natural grace, dignity, charm    and elegance of the actress. In this remake, it is completely    absent. You just see this curvy bimbo looking out the window from a distance.  <br /> <br />In the remake, there is no way for the audience to appreciate the lead character's feelings of relationship, and connection. So when he pursues her, it doesn't really make any sense. <br /> <br />I could go on and on about why this movie is vastly inferior to the original. Instead, let me just say that I could only bear watching this monstrosity for about twenty minutes. It is so hideous and unintelligent compared to the original, it is REMARKABLE!  How could this director ever have been given the money to butcher the movie in this way? He obviously didn't have the slightest understanding of the original, how it was put together and what made it work. <br /> <br />It is an example of Hollywood at its worst. Stupid people with lots of money who have no ability to analyze plots. Instead they just sign a couple of big stars and hope for the best. <br /> <br />Hanging would be too good.

B0000AOV85|5.0|This look at Pink Floyd's \\"The Dark Side of Moon\\" is a template for the entire Classic Albums series in terms of providing insights and not simply telling stories out of school.  On the one hand we have Roger Waters sitting with an acoustic guitar explaining and playing songs, and on the other there is engineer Alan Parson sitting in front of the mixing board not only explaining but also showing how they came up with some of the most memorable bits of this album.  In between (in more ways than one) is Dave Gilmour, who brings out a series of guitars to recreate bits and pieces of the songs and then puts on his glasses to play around with the mixing board himself, letting us here the layered guitars.  Never has a look at \\"how they did it\\" for a record album been more fascinating.  Nick Mason and Richard Wright are interviewed as well, so everybody gets their turn to talk about the legendary album that was on the Billboard charts for almost fourteen years.<br /><br />Waters wrote a series of songs that had as their subject matter the rather mundane aspects of life.  The result was that Pink Floyd was directed toward making a concept album and if there is a key revelation in this documentary it is that these songs were essentially constructed before they were mixed.  That is pretty amazing when you get the examples of the soundscapes and various effects that created some of the most richly textured music of that period (I wanted to ascribe a particular genre to the album but there is everything from psychadelia and art rock to jazz fusion and blues-rock on this album).  The documentary goes into detail track by track on the album, but obviously some songs will stand out more than others (e.g., \\"Money,\\" \\"Time\\").<br /><br />The deleted scenes are pretty substantial on this DVD and give you more of the same.  The end result is a sense of wonder at how every thing fell into place for the band to perfect the album.  My favorite story is about Parsons bringing in Claire Torry, an EMI staff songwriter and session vocalist, to do the wailing wordless vocals at the climax of \\"The Great Gig in the Sky.\\"  But there are also nice stories about saxophonist Dick Parry and the guys who did the voices.  Waters, Gilmour and Wright all play some of the songs on acoustic guitar, which gets contrasted with not only the finished tracks but also demo tapes.  There is also footage from the old days to remember that these old men were once rock stars who put together one of the great concept albums of the rock era.  The disharmony that would eventually rip Pink Floyd asunder is only hinted at when the conflicting visions of how \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\" should be mixed and does nothing to take away from enjoying this look at the classic album, which, of course, you will want to listen to again a couple of times after you watch this documentary.re Torry, an EMI staff songwriter and session vocalist, to do the wailing wordless vocals at the climax of \\"The Great Gig in the Sky.\\"   But there are also nice stories about saxophonist Dick Parry and the guys who did the voices.  Waters, Gilmour and Wright all play some of the songs on acoustic guitar, which gets contrasted with not only the finished tracks but also demo tapes.  There is also footage from the old days to remember that these old men were once rock stars who put together one of the great concept albums of the rock era.   The disharmony that would eventually rip Pink Floyd asunder is only hinted at when the conflicting visions of how \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\" should be mixed and does nothing to take away from enjoying this look at the classic album, which, of course, you will want to listen to again a couple of times after you watch this documentary.

It has all of the songs people who frequent the radio waves would want to have. So even if you hate Britney, as a lot of people do, you have to like at least one of her songs. It's just nuts not to. My personal favorite off of the album is probably the Darkchild remix of \\"Overprotected\\". And even for listeners who have all of her albums, this album has the appeal of unreleased or rare tracks. Such as the Overprotected remix, Do Somethin', My Prerogative, (I've Just Begun) Having My Fun, and the Neptunes \\"Co-Ed\\" remix of Boys featuring Pharrell.<br /><br />I see no reason why someone shouldn't want this album. It's a true piece of history. ALL of her songs since the start that have frequented the radio stations are present, for the most part.<br /><br />Well worth time, and money.

Gone was the polished days of Violator and their 80's look. Dave Gahan has let his hair grow, grown a beard and acquired numerous tattoos on his body. Songs like I feel you, Walking in my shoes and In your room sound like nothing they had done before and the major inclusion of guitars was a nice addition. Even though some fans hated it. The problem is that Alan Wilders contributions on this album add nothing and he seems to be totaly out of sync. Even so, I pin point the problem with Alan Wilder. He had totally taken control over the sound and now on this album he was running out of ideas and this makes the grade become 4 stars instead of 5.

B0006IIKS0|3.0|I just rented the documentary and I decided to look at the Amazon reviews afterwards.  Over a year ago I reviewed St. Anger for Amazon and I basically trashed it.   Turn the clock forward and now we have a documentary that essentially chronicles the making of St. Anger.      I maintain that St. Anger was a major disappointment for the band.  It was poorly mixed, poorly recorded, snare drum-laden to a ridiculous extent, and with lyrics that would make James Hetfield from 1987 puke continously.  Now after seeing this \\"documentary,\\" we finally realize why St. Anger was so weak. They had cameras on them while they were creating it.  You have three extremely self conscious muscicians trying to make up stuff on the spot.  That's tough to pull off for anyone.  And it failed miserably.     But the film itself: is cleverly done, has great historical footage, and shows many flashes of the former greatness of this epic band.  The film might have been much better if it didn't concentrate so heavily on the current problems and the performance therapist they employed, and concentrated more on why they became the highest grossing cd sales band of the 90's.      In 1986, when Metallica released their incredible album, Master of Puppets, most metal bands were yapping out silly songs with hair sprayed up to the rafters with dark spandex,purple shoes with sparkles, and sunken cheeks with hair extensions for some of the slightly balding lead singers.  The overall IQ of metal music was low.  Metallica was totally different: Metallica wore holey jeans and battered black t-shirts and sang about pain and played their instruments so hard and heavy that it looked like their guitars would become sawdust and strings by the end of their show.  They were an incredible band.  That's what is missing in this film.

B00064WSN2|2.0|After the successful 'In the court of the Crimson King', which was ground-breaking, members of the original band were abandoning ship. Guitar player Robert Fripp was basically left with lyricist Peter Sinfield, but was able to convince most of the band to stay to help him complete a second album.     With that in mind, Fripp had to kind of keep things going along nicely, so, a lot of the material is quite reminiscent of the material on the debut, actually very similar indeed. Well, the first half of the album kind of reminds the listener of the first side of the first album. The second side is a mish-mash of new sounds.     There is a folky ballad called 'Peace' that is broken up and spread throughout the album, which doesn't add much. 'Pictures of a city' and 'In the wake of Poseidon' are both flat when compared with the songs they mirror. The only really good song is 'Catfood', an eccentric up-tempo song that is fun and kind of predicts the type of music the band would make later on in their careers. This could also be said of 'The Devil's Triangle', a very dissonant sounding song full of eerie noises, but it's not very good. Though would do much better later with 'Lark's Tongues in Aspic', 'Fracture' and 'The Mincer' with this type of thing. 'Cadence and Cascade' is a lot like 'Talk to the wind', but at least Gordon Haskell gives a fresh feeling, as does a slightly different arrangement.     Overall, this album is not King Crimson at their best. They can do much better, but at least it is enjoyable if you like progressive music, albeit rather an average 'prog' record. Rating **

6305388458|4.0|Of course not.  Because in this day and age, I would be branded as a heretic or labeled insane and thus thrown out of the way in an insane asylum. The Catholic Church (and others) have changed so much that it isn't even the same thing anymore.  People misinterpret things whether it be a gourd or a sandal, and it becomes completely out of hand.  I know that this isn't necessarily the right place to post it, but as an atheist, I feel that God exists to explain the unexplained.  With that out of the way, let's continue with the review.  It's absolutely filled with laughs.  I could hardly stay still when the roman guard had Brian correct the misspellings of his graffiti.  The Bigus Dicus scene is absolutely classic and the even more classic \\"always look on the bright side of life\\" (curse my lack of ability to whistle).  There are only a few problems with this DVD.  One, this is a poor DVD, there is only one disc, and hardly and extras worth paying attention to.  The far better Criterion collation version has that second disc that Holy Grail and Meaning of life possess yet for some reason for life of Brian is 30 dollars, whereas Meaning of Life and Holy Grail are significantly cheaper then the superior version of Brian.  The second problem which is not quite as irritating is that for me (and this may only have been for me) I find that their accents are a lot thicker in this film.  I enjoy the English accent as much as the next guy, but some times, I find myself going \\"what he just say?\\" and having to find myself rewinding so I can focus better to see what that last line was.  That still doesn't affect the overall impact and message of the film or its brave humor or its originality.  This movie deserves 5 stars but this DVD is getting 4 for the lack of features and inferiority to the overpriced 2 Criterion collection version.  The Life of Brian may challenge the idea of organized religion, but it is not made to offend anybody.  It makes a valuable point but the only ones who were really shocked or appalled by this film were us Americans.  Fellow reviewer Isala has explained why, so I won't repeat what they said.  If you are unsure of this film still, then rent it.  If you then find yourself offended, then you just have to loosen up and relax a bit.  That's pretty much all I have to say.  Try to get the Criterion collection for a low price if you're a big fan, but if you are a casual fan then this version will do just fine.  Hoped this helped.

B00000J2KV|4.0|When I was an exchange student in Chile in 1969, I became familiar with the term \\"Lolito\\".  It was what they called a young person who acted like they were older than they actually were.  Back then in the US we called them \\"teeny-boppers\\".  I asked my Chilean friends where the term \\"Lolito\\" came from.  They were surprized that I didn't know the term since it was from an American movie.  That, and not the book or the movie, was my introduction to \\"Lolita\\". <br /> <br />I read the book by Nabokov some years ago.  It didn't appeal to me and, other than remembering that it was about an older man's sexual obsession with a 12 year old girl, I don't recall any of the plot.  I finally had the opportunity to see the movie last night and I was left with a mixed reaction.  This is a quality-made movie with excellence in directing, acting, writing, editing, and cinematography.  Peter Sellers gives an outstanding multi-role preformance and Shelly Winters and James Mason are very good in their roles.  Sue Lyon is probably better than I'm tempted to give her credit for because she creates a somewhat annoying personality of a youth at that age.  I was certain that I saw Miss Moneypenny from James Bond famein the role of Nurse Mary.  I checked it out and it was her.   <br /> <br />The movie diverts from the book in that the movie comes across as black comedy.  We are invited to see the humor in the sexual relationship between a sexual predator and a 14 year old girl.  I guess that is what black humor is supposed to do; make us laugh at situations not normally associated with humor.  I found myself drawn uncomfortably into the humor but I was more interested in what happened to the main characters.  This is where I felt that the movie let me down.   <br /> <br />\\"Lolita\\" is, for me, the tragic-comedy of the obsession of a man and how that obsession methodically destroyed him.  It is a brilliant movie in that respect.  However, there is a young girl whom, the movie leads us to believe, was \\"inconvenienced\\" by this premature sexual relationship with a man nearly 4 times her age.  There are a number of scenes which skillfully depict the loss of her youth but we tend to understand these sacrifices as a sort of \\"grounding\\".  Other than disappointment, we see little effect on Lolita.  She eventually picks up her life and goes on as though little if anything happened.   <br /> <br />I confess that I could be found guilty of over-analyzing an otherwise excellent movie but that is how I reacted to \\"Lolita\\".  It seems odd to say but, with the the modern-day \\"awareness\\" that grew out of political correctness, this movie probably found a more receptive audience in 1962 than it would have today.  Back then in was scandalous, today it would be considered insensitive.  I think I would have preferred to see \\"Lolita\\" when it was merely scandalous.  Maybe too much sensitivity makes us insensitive.

I just hate seeing such a good player doing this kind of music. Before his playing has been something that i've never experienced before. For example Steve Vai is a good guitarist, but he's a bad musician. Most of his music is boring and unoriginal... it's meaning is only to show how technically proficient he is... I think petruccis playing has gone to the same point in ToT... his solos have no idea... or atleast if there were an idea you couldn't here it because it's played so fast its. Playing fast should be a tool to accomplish expressing a feeling for example or something. Fast parts should balancethe slow parts to make the music more alive. Speed shouln't be the purpose itself like on ToT it is. The album has it's good moments too. Vacant balances the albums heavy songs, and does a great job at it. Stream of Conciousness i think is the best song off of the album...the most musical and it has a good feeling to it in the name of god is also great but maybe a bit too long. As for the first 4 songs... they are awful. As i am,The dying soul and honor thy father sound almost like any angry teen music... they have their good parts also but it doesn't help much. Endless sacrifice has atleast some effort. After hearing other DT albums, it isn't just enough that the songs are ok, they have to have something that makes me listen to them over and over again. The 4 first songs definantly aren't those kinds of songs. I think everyone of you who read these appreciate good music... otherwise you wouldn't listen to dream theater. Because of this i have to suggest you all listen to a german band called Superior. I think it's the best that heavy metal as a genre can offer. The singer is amazing and their music is just incredible compared to train of thought. And if many of you consider Train of Thought good... well you should really listen to it. Please e-mail me if you something you would like to say or maybe try to convert me into liking the album :)
